sp.p: You don't know what a cruel blow it is, to be disappointed when you have set your heart on a charming creature, who, receiving besides —

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: Yes, I know,but there are other charming creatures who having been careful of their wages and perquisites, have a nice little bit of money.

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: I don't care about money, but such a man as I am ought not to go to any woman for nothing; and when I hear of sensible females who have saved some money, I always wish that I could marry them all, and take them and their property in a lump. But where find these charming creatures ?

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: Well, here is one of them.

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: You ? you have saved a sum of money ?

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: Yes, I have lived in this service almost from my childhood, and have been very careful.

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: Martin, my dear, I have long entertained a secret affection for you.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: For Phœbe you mean ?

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: Never I what do I care for the poor burnt-out wretch ? My grief for her loss was all a pretence, because my manly pride could not endure that you should behold a love I feared you could never requite.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: Why should you fear that, and you in such a responsible situation, and such a fine and portly man.

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: I was, till I lost my (placing his hand on his stomach)

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: If I must confess it, I have long entertained a partiality for you, Mr. Bibbles.

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: And you are the girl that I have all my life been looking for.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: Your noble presence, your dignified bearing —

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: Your sparkling eyes, and the bit of money you have saved —

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: I always said my husband should be a fine, tall, stout man.

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: And I made up my mind that my wife should be a little creature, timid as a fawn, and slim and delicate as a clothes prop. Come to my majestic arms, (embracing her)
sp.stage: Enter Bubbles, R.

sp.speaker: Bubbles.
sp.p: Oh! here's goings on. Is it part of a butler's duty to cuddle the female domestics ?

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: What business have you here? None at all with this young lady of property, I am quite certain.

sp.speaker: Bubbles.
sp.p: No, for I see that it's you who are the man in possession.

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: Bubbles.
sp.p: I thought you wouldn't bear malice, and as I am out of place—nobody seems to know when they have got a steady, and sober young man !

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: Why you are drunk now !

sp.speaker: Bubbles.
sp.p: That's to celebrate my return to sobriety, for I left off drinking half an hour ago, and I'll never drink any more !

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: Give him one more trial ?

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: At this blissful moment I can refuse you nothing, dearest!

sp.speaker: Bubbles.
sp.p: And you shall find that I'll be sober every day of my life—(aside) and I won't let him see me when I'm drunk every night.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: How is Luke Marks ?

sp.speaker: Bubbles.
sp.p: Dead! burnt and crushed; couldn't get over it. I am sorry to say he was far from being a sober young man !

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: Oh ! gracious, then, Phœbe is now a widow !

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Bibbles, what is that to you ?

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.p: Nothing my love, merely an observation, nothing more, (aside—crosses, L.) I forgot for the moment that the charming was no longer receiving her lady with a liberal besides, and—no—that's not right; but never mind.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.l: Upon the hill brow is the church you know,
And thither we soon will hie.

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.l: And when we are wed, we'll have such a spread,
And to eat a good lot I'll try;
With lots of choicest wine—
That's quite understoood;

sp.speaker: Bubbles.
sp.l: And I'll drink it, drink it, drink it, drink it,
'Cause I know it's good.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: And we'll drink it, &c, &c,
'Cause we know its good.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.l: I'll talk very loud, and I'll feel very proud,
When I am a butler's wife.

sp.speaker: Bibbles.
sp.l: And we'll have a boy, to be our joy
And the glory of our life;
To make him grow up smart,
I'll do the best I can.

sp.speaker: Bubbles.
sp.l: And make him a steady, steady, steady, steady, and sober man.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: And we'll make him, a steady, steady, steady,
steady, and sober man ;
Fol, lol, tol, lol, &c. Reel, sing, and dance off, L.

div.stage: Scene fifth .—Apartment as before.
Music .— Robert, L., Sir Michael, R., looking horror-stricken on Lady Audley, who is C., crouching on both knees before him, her face covered with her hands.

sp.speaker: Sir M.
sp.p: I cannot hear any more of this terrible secret which, now revealed to me, must embitter all the years yet left to me. Robert, you will not act too harshly with her whom I have thought—my wife. You will remember in all you do, that I have loved her very dearly and truly. I cannot say farewell to her. I can but pity her, as I now pray that heaven may pity her. (going slowly, R.)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (raising her head) I should be sorry for you if I could, for you have been very good to me; but I can't, I can't. I can feel nothing but my own misery. I have ever been selfish, now more selfish than ever in my misery. Happy, prosperous people may feel for others — I laugh at other people's sufferings, they seem so small compared to my own. (Sir Michael goes dejectedly off, D. R. ; Lady Audley rising) Let me go—my brain is on fire, (crosses, L.)

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: My uncle may believe that you are insane—I do not deem you mad, but dangerous; yet, for all our sakes, madness shall be supposed the excuse for your crimes, and the rest of your life shall pass in the mad woman's proper home.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (alarmed) What mean you ?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: A lunatic asylum, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: No, no, not that, oh, heaven! not that.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: It is a fate too merciful for you—double murderess, that you are!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Double murderess ?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, Luke Marks is dead of the hurts received in the fire you kindled.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Ah! but you shall not take me to a madhouse— I will not be buried while yet alive—I would laugh at you and defy you if I dared. I would kill myself and defy you if I dared. But I am a poor pitiful coward, and have been so from the first, afraid of my mother's horrible inheritance, afraid of poverty, afraid of George Talboys, afraid of you; but you shall not take me to a madhouse, you shall not! you shall not! (rushing wildly off, L.)

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I will do that which I think just to others and merciful to her—I will give her time and opportunity for repentance.
sp.stage: Enter George Talboys, hastily, R. door, very pale.

sp.speaker: Talboys.
sp.p: Robert! Robert I dear friend.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: (recoiling, amazed) Great heavens! George Talboys, and living!

sp.speaker: Talboys.
sp.p: Yes, yes, dear friend, (they embrace)

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I have mourned you as dead; believed that your wife—but, where have you been ? Why did she confess to having slain you, if—oh I can it be true that she is mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Talboys.
sp.p: Luke Marks rescued me, with much difficulty, from the well into which I had fallen, after receiving the murderous blow intended for my slaughter; he conveyed me to his home, and there I have languished until now, his prisoner. His death has set me free.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: And why—why ——

sp.speaker: Talboys.
sp.p: That he might have power o'er my wife—I mean o'er Lady Audley. Oh ! Robert, you will be silent I could not bear to see her perish shamefully. I will return to foreign climes, and leave her to the wealth and splendour she has sinned so horribly to obtain.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Oh! too late, too late for that; to Sir Michael she has confessed her guilt—and now —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (entering totteringly, L.) I shall not go to a madhouse—I shall not! I—(seeing Talboys and standing petrified) Ah! It is his spirit!—I have seen it in my dreams! but thus—oh! mercy !—mercy !

sp.speaker: Talboys.
sp.p: Helen, let it comfort you to know that you have failed in your dreadful purpose—that I pardon you, and will go where you may never more behold me—where I shall be as though I were, indeed, dead to you !

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Talk not to me thus; it is to mock my agony, for I am dying!

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Dying!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Your threat (to Robert)—the madhouse! I have taken poison—death is on me even now ! (sinking to the ground) If I had but delayed a few minutes only!—but this torture heaven had reserved for the supreme moment ! Oh, agony more terrible than those with which the poison racks my frame ! but 'tis almost over. You will not give my memory to infamy ? No, you will not dare !—for your own sakes you will not dare ! and buried in the grave with her will be "Lady Audley's Secret"—ah!

div.stage: (half raises herself, presses both hands to her heart, and falls back dead; Sir Michael appears, door R., and gazes on her with grief and terror; Talboys kneels beside her, covering his face with his hands; Robert raises his hands towards heaven. Music)
